titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Peter V. Cacchione Papers TAM.073
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Phyllis Klein

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Cacchione Guide.wpd

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-10-09T11:45-0400

change.item: Series V edited by Nicole Greenhouse. Conditions governing use note updated for accuracy.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in ten manuscript boxes and one oversized flat box.

did.abstract: Peter V. Cacchione was a labor leader, communist and New York City councilman. He took advantage of New York City's proportional representation system, and ran (unsuccessfully) for city council on the Communist Party ticket in 1937 and 1939. He was elected in 1941, 1943 and 1945 and served until his death in 1947. The collection includes his correspondence, speeches, wiritings, clippings, etc. from 1936-1947. Researchers must use microfilm (R-7823), except for series V, Scrapbooks.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research without restrictions. Patrons must use microfilm (Film R-7823, Reels 1-4), except for Series V: Scrapbooks.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Peter V. Cacchione (November 1, 1897 - November 6, 1947) was a labor leader, communist and New York City councilman. He was born of immigrant parents in Syracuse, New York in 1897, and grew up in Sayre, Pennsylvania. After graduating from high school in 1915 he worked as a railroad trainman and repairman, and at other blue-collar jobs. In 1932 he moved to New York, where he joined the progressive movement and in 1935 was elected National Commander of the Workers' Ex-Servicemen's League. In 1936 he became chairman of the Communist Party in the Bronx.

After moving to Brooklyn, he took advantage of New York City's newly instituted proportional representation system and ran (unsuccessfully) for city council on the Communist Party ticket in 1937 and 1939. He was elected in 1941, reelected in 1943 and 1945, and served until his death in 1947, two days after proportional representation was repealed. The New York City Council refused to seat the Communist Party's choice to serve the remaining fourteen months of Cacchione's term, his campaign manager (and biographer) Simon W. Gerson.

list.item: Simon W. Gerson. Pete: the Story of Peter V. Cacchione, New York's First Communist Councilman, New York: International Publishers, 1976.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series, arranged chronologically, includes John Cashmore, Luther Hill, Paul O'Dwyer, Michael J. Quill, Leo Rayfield, Nathan Sobel, Andrew Sommer, Henry Stimson, Harry S. Truman, Robert F. Wagner, Henry A. Wallace, and Walter Wilson.

The Speeches and Writings series contains It Happened at City Hall (Cacchione's Daily Workercolumn) and other articles, radio addresses, news releases, two unpublished Cacchione play typescripts, "Builders of America" and "Pageant for Columbus Day," and two book-length unpublished typescripts "What is Public Speaking?" and "A Few Simple Hints to Speakers," which are notable (especially the latter) for their use of 'how-to' examples based on numerous accounts of contemporary political issues, many at the grassroots level and ephemeral in nature.

The Topical Files series (arranged alphabetically) contains multiple files on discrimination, electoral campaigns (PVC, others), the five cent (bus and subway) fare, housing, proportional representation, resolutions (City Council and other) wartime price controls, and individual files on other local issues, and on Cacchione's 1947 national speaking tour.

The City Council series largely consists of PVC-issued Budget Questionnaire forms completed by officials of several hundred New York State cities, towns, and villages, and various documents and ephemera.
The last series consists of scrapbooks and loose material removed from scrapbooks (not microfilmed) documenting Cacchione's political career from 1939 to 1945.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence; II. Speeches and Writings; III. Topical Files; IV. City Council; V. Scrapbooks (not microfilmed).
Folders are arranged alphabetically within each series.

altformavail.head: Microfilm
altformavail.p: This collection, with the exception of Series V: Scrapbooks, is available on microfilm (Film R-7823, Reels 1-4) for use in this repository only. Researchers must use microfilm for this collection, except Series V.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Peter V. Cacchione are held by Dorothy Cacchione. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which she holds copyright must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Tamiment Library for assistance with contacting Dorothy Cacchione.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number;
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Researchers must use the microfilmed version of Series I-IV; microfilm call number is R7823.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: In 2014, clippings from scrapbooks were re-foldered. Additional description for the scrapbooks was added to the finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials from disassembled scrapbooks. It includes clippings, election materials related to Cacchione's run for councilman, holiday cards, correspondence, event invitations and programs, flyers related to Communist Party campaigns and events, and articles by and about Cacchione. The series also contains an oversized Scrapbook which includes clippings, flyers, press releases, and a small number of photographs relating to Cacchione's political career.
